we say DevOps what are we talking about so it's really a few things right the way we talk about DevOps is it's a set
of cultural philosophies and practices that are implemented with a set of tools so there are many many many different
ways to implement DevOps within an organization you know the the general
the general anti-pattern that we're working against is the classical kind of Waterfall organization where you have a
development team and you've an Operations team and they sit across walls from each other and one finishes a
piece of work and throws it over the wall and then the other teams job to kind of operationalize that work the idea of
DevOps here it's a cultural philosophy where the whole team is responsible for
the development and operation of a product together from inception of the product or project to delivery and
operational deployment of that project and there are practices that are part of
that right things like continuous integration and continuous deployment continuous monitoring things like you
know some of the kind of extreme programming Kent Beck style practices of
project management and then there are tools that you can use to implement these practices so you know development
and operations coming together shared responsibility and ownership is really the high-order bit here it's not the
operations team responsibility solely that the product works it's everybody's
responsibility and visibility and communication so ensuring that people are working together you know there's
the the old agile manifesto from Snowbird from I guess 20 years ago now and there's a great you know one of the
lines in that is that we value individuals and interactions over processes and tools so at the bedrock of
the agile software development movement was getting people to work together getting people to speak with one another
and getting people to as a collective share responsibility for the success of
a project that's kind of the high order bit of DevOps in my opinion so a couple
of other practices that you often hear when we talk about DevOps so one is this idea of breaking down one large
application into many smaller applications or microservices architecture or service or services
oriented architecture this is not necessarily something that you know you can obviously be working in a team where
it's development operations working together to ship a single piece of code to production but often what teams find
is that breaking a large problem down into smaller problems that could be owned by a smaller set of people leads
to increased velocity right so if you think about we're going to talk a lot
about Amazon in a moment but if you think about the AWS console when you open up that 80s console is 125 little
icons in there there are literally tens of thousands of little teams that are
responsible for those right so across Amazon there are 10 you know tens of thousands of what we call two Pizza teams yeah they have a two Pizza team is
that if a project becomes so large in terms of people power that it takes more
than two pizzas to feed that team well you probably should break that team down right so the observation there is that

months or weeks and weeks or even days and days continually integrate your changes back into a single mainline or

continually coming back and ensuring that their changes all work together and all fit together okay so that's

endpoint of that where not only are you building that artifact but you're actually shipping it to production after
every check-in so every customer check-in code gets checked in it gets put to production through after going

automated to live pipeline is is basically a software manifestation of those manual steps that
